meanings.def: to move slowly, quietly and carefully, because you do not want to be seen or heard
examples: I crept up the stairs, trying not to wake my parents.
I heard someone creeping around the house.
He crept stealthily along the corridor.
He crept up behind me.
I could hear someone creeping around downstairs.
He crept forward towards the sound of voices.
She crept into her sister's room.
The cat was creeping stealthily through the long grass.

meanings.def: to move with your body close to the ground; to move slowly on your hands and knees
to move or develop very slowly
examples: Her arms crept around his neck.
A slight feeling of suspicion crept over me.
A feeling of dread crept over him.
Trucks are creeping along Interstate 70 in convoys.

meanings.def: to grow along the ground or up walls using long stems or roots
to be too friendly or helpful to somebody in authority in a way that is not sincere, especially in order to get an advantage from them
to make you feel afraid or full of horror
examples: Just the sight of him makes my flesh creep.
The story made his flesh creep.

idioms.def: to make you feel afraid or full of horror
examples: Just the sight of him makes my flesh creep.
The story made his flesh creep.

meanings.def: a person that you dislike very much and find very unpleasant
examples: He's a nasty little creep!
You little creep!

meanings.def: a person who is not sincere but tries to win your approval by being nice to you
examples: He’s the sort of creep who would do that kind of thing!

meanings.def: the development of a project beyond the goal that was originally agreed
examples: The World Bank has been accused of mission creep when seeking to address these concerns.
The inclusion of health data on identity cards was condemned as function creep.
creep of something We need to prevent this slow creep of costs.
The creep of suburban shopping malls is shrinking the countryside.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel nervous and slightly frightened, especially because somebody/something is unpleasant or strange
examples: This old house gives me the creeps.

idioms.def: to make somebody feel nervous and slightly frightened, especially because somebody/something is unpleasant or strange
examples: This old house gives me the creeps.
